awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Social Reception of Energy Infrastructure in the Developing World
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines the social reception of proposed energy projects in developing countries.  Promoting access to affordable, reliable, and modern energy -- especially in critical regions of South Asia and Africa -- is an important foreign policy priority of the United States. Despite the scale of unmet demand, social protest and contestation have become a barrier to project realization in many communities. Yet the origins and impact of such contention are poorly understood. Having a better understanding of the factors that drive protest will enhance American economic competitiveness and inform foreign policy. As American public institutions and private firms commonly provide funding and technology for energy ventures abroad, the research is disseminated through targeted publications and a public conference with relevant governmental, industry, financial, and non-governmental stakeholders. In addition, this study contributes to education and research infrastructure. Specifically, it generates public data sets and documentation of the associated methodology that will be useful to other researchers. It also trains underrepresented undergraduate and graduate researchers.

This project advances scholarly knowledge by contributing to the comparative politics of infrastructure siting and social protest. It offers three main advances.  First, it pioneers a method for the global comparative study of protest events, demonstrating how traditional and social media records can be leveraged to gather reliable data about social contestation. Second, it combines original data on protest with existing data on proposed coal projects all over the world, developing insight into how the politics of project siting may differ in the developed and developing world. Third, it offers a multi-faceted treatment of how protest affects outcomes, including consideration of the potential for protest to impact both project and community-level outcomes. The project employs a multi-method approach to data collection and analysis that includes statistical methods, focus group discussions, and qualitative case studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Expanding energy production is an important priority globally. This project examined the social reception of proposed energy projects in developing countries. It asked: what explains variation in public opposition to proposed energy projects? What influence does social contestation have on project-level and community-level outcomes? The project’s theory emphasized the importance of developer identity, hypothesizing the foreign developers would be more likely to face social opposition.

The project involved four stages of data collection and analysis. In a first stage, a team of research assistants used existing data on coal and wind projects to catalogue characteristics of those projects and communities. These project data were matched with original data on protest to statistically analyze the drivers of social contestation, promoting external validity. In a second stage, the researchers conducted qualitative interviews with a sample of respondents located in India, South Africa, and Turkey, exploring attitudes around energy development and mechanisms that link developer identity and contention, enhancing internal validity. Third, the project used statistical analysis to identify the impact of protest on the likelihood of projects being cancelled or altered. And fourth, we selected two communities in Turkey for in-depth case studies that consider how the experience of protest affects the communities' political and energy development outcomes. 

The statistical analyses of this project consistently find that the presence of foreign developers increases the likelihood of an energy project being opposed. This is true for both coal and wind projects. The effect applies generally to foreign developers but is particularly pronounced for Chinese foreign developers. Qualitative interviews in Turkey, South Africa, and India suggest that individuals perceive foreign developers as less likely to provide jobs, more likely to skirt local rules, and more likely to bring social disruption to their community. Statistical analyses and case studies from Turkey also show that projects that are opposed are more likely to be cancelled and are rarely replaced with different projects. Overall, these findings suggest that public opposition is common and foreign developers in the energy sector can and should take actions to improve social acceptance.

The project yielded several key outcomes. The principal investigator (PI) has three peer-reviewed publications under review, all of which are co-authored with graduate students who worked on this project.  The PI also published a public-facing memo on the topic and is drafting a white paper on the results from the wind project analysis.  The project also had several broader impacts.  The PI held a public-facing virtual workshop to disseminate the project results, including 35 participants from academia, the non-profit sector, industry, and government. The data from the project will be made publicly available at the time of publication, enhancing the available data infrastructure in this area. The project also contributed to human resources by training future scientists, most of whom are from backgrounds underrepresented in science. Undergraduate and graduate students gained educational benefits by learning about how to conduct qualitative interviews, build datasets, and publish research.
